_exec_summary.SummaryText:
The Plan describes procedures implemented by Wilbur-Ellis Company, Agribusiness Division ("Wilbur-Ellis") to prevent accidental releases of ammonia that could cause harm to the public and the environment from short-term exposures.  The Plan includes an analysis of the potential offsite consequences of an accidental release, a five-year accident history, and a release prevention and emergency response program.  

Accidental Release Prevention and Emergency Response Policies

Wilbur-Ellis has implemented release prevention and emergency response procedures to minimize the potential for accidental releases of hazardous materials.  Emergency response procedures including evacuation procedures and notification procedures have been implemented by Wilbur-Ellis.  In addition, Wilbur-Ellis has developed operating procedures and preventative maintenance activities to reduce the likelihood of accidental releases.

This Plan and the emergency response procedures document the accidental release prevention, safety, and emergency policies in place at Wilbur-Ellis.

Description of Stationary Source and Regulated Substances

Wilbur-Ellis is located at 113 Highway 8 in Troy, Idaho (the "facility").  Wilbur-Ellis is a retailer of fertilizer in the form of anhydrous ammonia stored under pressure.  Twice annually, a tanker is delivered to the facility and parked for use as a temporary storage vessel for anhydrous ammonia.  The tanker has a capacity of approximately 10,500 gallons.  The anhydrous ammonia is transferred from the tanker into one 800-gallon applicator or one tender truck containing two 1,000-gallon tanks.  The contents of the applicator or the tender truck are sold to the local farming community for use as fertilizer.  

General Accidental Release Prevention Program and Chemical Specific Prevention Steps
  
Wilbur-Ellis has developed and implemented this Plan with the objective of complying with the requirements and guidelines set forth by the Federal Risk Man

agement Plan program.  The Plan's purpose is to enhance the facility's existing safety programs implemented at the site to reduce the possibility of accidental releases of anhydrous ammonia that could cause harm to employees, the public and the environment.  The emergency response program, documented in the emergency response procedures, includes accidental release prevention and chemical specific prevention steps.

Wilbur-Ellis ensures that equipment meets the appropriate industry standards prior to use.  Wilbur-Ellis implements operating procedures and maintenance procedures in accordance with manufacturer and industry specifications to prevent accidental releases at the facility.  Chemical specific prevention steps implemented at the site include excess flow valves, pressure relief valves, emergency shut off valves with cables that run along the length of the horizontal storage tanks for quick access, and ammonia training for personnel.
 
Five-Year Accident History

There have been no qualifying accidents involving ammonia in the five-year period prior to the completion of this Plan.

Emergency Response Program

The facility coordinates with the Troy Fire Department ("fire department") regarding specific actions to be taken in response to an accidental release of anhydrous ammonia.  The facility has established emergency evacuation procedures to evacuate the site and notify the appropriate agencies regarding a release.  The facility's emergency response program is documented in the facility's Emergency Response Procedures.  The emergency procedures contain the following key elements:

1.	Procedures for informing local agencies responsible for responding to accidental releases.
2.	Information on emergency health care.
3.	Emergency response training for employees.

Planned Changes to Improve Safety

Plans to improve safety at the facility were developed based on the results of compliance audits, hazard reviews, and a Risk Management Plan (RMP) sit

e inspection conducted by an outside contractor.  The Branch Manager is currently working on an implementation schedule for the recommended actions.  The recommended action includes the following:

1.	Install barricades around the location where the tanker will be stored when on site to prevent impact from vehicular traffic.
